subject: Art
title: Deliberate Practice
description: Practicing with specific goals rather than repeating what you already know.

hook.text: Drawing the same thing you're good at isn't practice â€” it's performance. Deliberate practice targets your weaknesses with specific, challenging exercises. It's uncomfortable by design because comfort means you're not growing.

buildup.text: Deliberate practice framework: 1) Identify a specific weakness ('my hands look stiff'). 2) Find targeted exercises (draw 50 gesture hands). 3) Get feedback (compare to reference or ask others). 4) Adjust and repeat.

discovery.text: The key: focus on ONE skill per session. Not 'get better at drawing' (too vague) but 'improve hand gesture accuracy' (specific and measurable). Focused practice on one thing for 20 minutes beats scattered practice on everything for an hour.

twist.text: Deliberate practice feels like failure â€” because you're constantly working at the edge of your ability. If it feels easy, you're not practicing; you're performing. Discomfort is the signal that growth is happening.

climax.text: Identify your biggest weakness right now. Design a 20-minute exercise that targets it specifically. Do it. It will feel frustrating and awkward. Good â€” that's the feeling of a skill being built.

punchline.text: Practice doesn't make perfect. DELIBERATE practice makes better. Target, stretch, fail, adjust, repeat.

quiz.question: What distinguishes deliberate practice from casual practice?
options: Deliberate practice targets specific weaknesses with focused exercises, feedback, and adjustment rather than repeating comfortable skills
